awd_titl_txt: Stochastic Analysis and Numerics for Large Scale Dynamical Systems, with Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasing complexity of banking systems and other large-scale networks subject to random effects, incomplete or partial observations, and systemic risk, put increasing demands for new and efficient mathematical tools for their analysis. This award addresses three projects in the stochastic and computational analysis of "large-scale" dynamical systems, in the sense that they are set in spaces of very high dimensions or involve the interactions of a large number of participating agents in the system. The first project will focus on the development of efficient numerical schemes for partial differential equations (PDEs) with a large number of spatial dimensions. These schemes could have a significant impact on computation-oriented financial instruments, such as model-based trading algorithms involving very-large portfolios. The second project and third projects study the structures of large financial systems that are interacting in a centralized (mean-field) and non-centralized (network) manner, respectively. The results will provide tools for the measurement and management of systemic risk, particularly default contagion for large scale interbank lending markets, both for individual investors and for regulators. The award will also result in the involvement and training of graduate students and dissemination through journal publications and conferences. 

The first project will develop efficient Monte-Carlo methods  for high-dimensional PDEs and path-dependent PDEs (PPDEs). These schemes are expected to be efficient when the dimension of the equations is allowed to be in the hundreds or higher, hence essentially breaking the notorious "curse of dimensionality" that has been baffling the numerical analysts and computer scientists for decades. The second project explore various theoretical issues as well as several practical problems in stochastic game/control theory and quantitative finance under the general framework of master equations and their variations. This project will utilize several recently developed technical tools, including the time consistency principle and the dynamic utility approach. The third project on dynamic systemic risk investigates a complex network in which the contagion effect among banks are described in a time-consistent, and non-centralized manner. By considering the state space of probability measures, the dynamical movements of networks can be described by measure-valued SDEs, while the systemic risk is characterized by certain master equations. All projects in the proposed research have direct or indirect connections to applied fields, especially to stochastic finance/actuarial sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. The PIs' completed works mainly focus on developing fundamental tools in mean field theory, set valued analysis, and numerical analysis for related problems. Especially, the works in mean field game theory provide new methodologies for the mean field game master equation, an infinite dimensional PDE on the space of probability measures, and have expanded the scope of its well-posedness dramatically; the works in set-valued analysis propose a new approach for several classes of applied problems which were typically considered ill-posed in the standard literature, and may open new research fields on this important subject.

During the award period, the two PIs have completed a total of 23 papers. The main works fall into the following categories:

1. Mean field problems, including mean field games, mean field controls, mean field optimal stopping problems, and McKean-Vlasov and conditional McKean-Vlasov equations. Such problems are inspired by many applications, especially on large interacting particle systems and various problems in finance, and have received very strong attention in the literature. The series of works on this subject have established the well-posedness for the related equations in quite general situations and/or proposed new notions of (weak) solutions and superpositions for these equations.

2. Set valued analysis. The PIs have proposed the set valued approach for time inconsistent problems, nonzero sum stochastic differential games and mean field games with multiple equilibria, and voting problems. One crucial property of these dynamic set valued functions is the time consistency, which motivates the PIs to propose new notions of set valued equations, including set valued PDEs and backward SDEs. This requires some fundamental tools such as set valued Ito formula and some deeper and innovative study of the notion of set valued stochastic integrals.

3. Time inconsistent problems. Time inconsistency appears naturally in economics/finance, for example in behavioral finance, contract theory, and games. The PIs have investigated several problems that are time inconsistent in nature in these applications, and provided a new perspective that is different from the existing approaches for attacking the issue.  

4.Stochastic two-point boundary value problems. These problems extend the so-called conditioned SDE and the dynamic Markov bridge and have connections to many “time-reversed” problems in dynamic systems. It proves to be an efficient tool in studying the Kyle-Back strategic insider trading equilibrium models and is closely related to the notion of Martin boundary of harmonic functions, as well as the score-based generative models  and the Schrödinger bridge in machine learning.

5. Stochastic finance and insurance problems. The PIs have also worked on problems in the field of finance and insurance using the tools developed or connected to the proposed research. These include a project on a long-standing open problem on the optimal dividend and investment strategies under the Sparre Andersen insurance model, that is, the claim frequency is a renewal process; and a continuous time equilibrium model of limit order book in which the liquidity dynamics follows a non-local, reflected mean-field SDE with evolving intensity, whose frontier and shape are studied via a mean-field stochastic control problem.

6. Numerical analysis for related problems. We provide the convergence analysis for mean field optimal stopping problems and propose efficient numerical methods for some stochastic volatility models which are by nature path dependent. 

Broader Impacts. Most works reported above are either directly aiming at or providing mathematical tools for problems arising from economics and finance. The relevant applications include: behavioral finance, rough volatility models, stochastic optimizations with asymetric information, systemic risk,  and political economy. The PIs have been presenting their research findings in numerous conferences and seminars, both domestic and international. During the award period eight Ph.D students have finished their dissertations under the PIs' supervision, with four of them working in academia and the other four working in financial industry, and another three PhD students are working on their thesis. The PI has been serving in the graduate committee at USC Math Department, and the co-PI has been the Director of the USC Math Finance Master program. The PIs have been running the Math Finance Colloquium at USC, and have been serving as an Associate Editor of a total of twelve journals during the award period.
